title: How to get 8 hours worth of sleep in 3 hours or less - Quora

response.answer_text: You can do it by sleeping for 4.5 hours instead of 4. Please note that you must cut down on your sleep only occasionally on the days where a dire need exists. If you make lesser sleep a habit, you will hurt your health and peace of mind in the long run. That said, a complete sleep is not about sleeping for 8 hours.  For example, you can wake up tired even after sleeping for about 8 hours or you can even wake up fresh by sleeping for only 3 hours or 4.5 hours. Are you thinking “That’s impossible for me. I sleep over 7 hours but still feel sleepy in the morning.” You wake up tired because you did not wake up at the right time. Waking up 20 minutes earlier could have changed this all. You can wake up fresh with lesser sleep by understanding the concept of sleep cycles. The ideal time to wake up is based on the time you go to sleep. If you get into bed exactly the same time every night, the wake-up time is as easy as eating a cake. It will be at the same time every day. Unfortunately, we have dishes to do, TV to watch, an unexpected phone call to answer and so on, making it difficult to go to bed at the same time every day. In most cases for most people, going to bed at the same time is like the timing of a flight departure. There is a time of departure mentioned but we already know that it won't be accurate. Similarly, since your sleeping time varies you have to calculate the ideal time to wake up on a daily basis by understanding sleep cycles.  Calculating your wake up time using Sleep Cycles: Sleep consists of sleep cycles of 90 min or 1.5 hours each. Every night you go through multiple sleep cycles. The hack that you can use is, to ensure you wake up towards the end of the sleep cycle. If you wake up in the middle of a sleep cycle, the cycle is broken and you wake up exhausted. If you wake up towards the end of one cycle or early in the next cycle, you tend to remain fresh. Please note that the sleep cycle starts after you fall asleep(not when you get into bed). Therefore, you must also take into account the time you need to fall asleep. As per statistics, most people need 14 mins to fall asleep after they get into bed. Let us take an example. If you get into bed at 10:45 PM and fall asleep at 11 PM, the ideal time for you to wake up is around the mark of 12:30 AM, 2 AM, 3:30 AM, 5 AM, 6:30 AM and so on. If you didn’t notice, all these slots are multiple of 90 mins since you fell asleep. Waking up at 12:20 AM or 2:10 AM or 5:05 AM is fine and will still keep you fresh. Waking up at 1:30 AM or 5:30 AM is breaking your sleep cycle waking you up at a point that you hate getting out of bed. In simple words, aim to wake up within the last 10 or the first 10 minutes of a sleep cycle. Do not wake up in the 10–80 minute window of the sleep cycle. On the long run, it is recommended to sleep for at least 6 hours on average. You can still wake up fresh with 3 or 4.5 hours of sleep daily, but it is not a good habit to follow in the long run. How many hours of sleep is good for you is subjective and varies from person to person. Some people manage with only 4.5 hours of sleep while some need 6 or 7.5 hours. Since there is some math involved, you can avoid all those calculations by using this link when you hit the bed - What time should I wake up to not feel tired? It tells you what time should you wake up. The green slots indicate sufficient sleep while the orange slots indicate shortage or excess sleep in the long run. It takes into account the 14 minutes that you need to fall asleep too. All you need to do is pick a slot among the many slots on the link and set your alarm.

Here’s a challenge for you. Put the four fingers of your non-dominant hand (if you’re right-handed that’s your left hand, and left-handed then it’s your right!) on these keys on your keyboard. D F G H Now in a moment press them in the following order: FHGD. Not yet! Do this as quickly as you can and time it - see how many times you can manage it properly (FGHD isn’t good enough) in 30 seconds. Okay, go! Do the same thing again tomorrow. Guess what? Without any further practice you’ll almost certainly have improved! (No refunds if it doesn’t happen, though!) Why? Because while you slept your mind will have been working on helping you learn that. And a thousand other things you’ve taken in during the day. … But there’s more - a lot more. Sleep also performs a range of vital services that we know about, and there may well be others of which we’re unaware. So we need to be aware that there may be risks tampering with its structure or duration. We need sleep that operates in a very specific way. People with depression, for instance, go into a dream state far earlier than others, and although there is insufficient evidence to draw confident conclusions, this may be one of the reasons why they wake feeling they haven’t benefitted from it. There is a specific structure and specific lengths of time to our dreams and non-dream states. Our dreams increase in length as we go through the night, and in between them we have periods when we seem to be ‘thinking’ without conscious awareness. Tampering with these natural systems may not be wise. In addition, we need to be aware of the many other functions sleep can provide so long as we don’t mess with it: Our brain cells contract during the night so that waste material such as dead cells can be cleared. Our body’s core temperature has to drop during our sleep - rats that were prevented from doing this died after just two weeks. Clearly this temperature drop is vital although we aren’t yet sure as to what function it performs. In addition there are a number of other known benefits that come from sleep, such as the body repairing and healing itself, emotional issues being addressed, and the storing of information. Further, we know that long-term sleep deficiency can cause a range of major problems - including, in the long-term, dementia. So many wonderful things happen when we’re asleep! There are claims that we can cut down sleep and not be affected, but I’ve yet to see reasonable proof of this. So I can only recommend that you allow yourself to sleep as nature has determined rather than trying to overrule her. Perhaps there is a way to compress sleep, but what happens to the hours you spend dreaming? And what about the time you seem to need where you aren’t dreaming? What we do know is that usually if you are sleep-deprived then you will do less well in all sorts of ways - including in the DFGH test! Good luck.

I would say there are a few things you can do for effective sleep that may “feel” like you got 9 hours sleep. However I would never recommend getting 4 hours of sleep if you can help it! Here are some good tips: 1.) Do not be around blue light before bed (your phone, tv, tablet, kindle…..). It can keep your brain from being truly ready for sleep, sort of like taking a nap after being active in the sun. 2.) Do yoga/meditate/do a pre-sleep activity. Have a sleep pre-game mentality, something you do every night before sleep. I read before bed every night. I have trained my body to think: reading=bedtime. Have a routine before bed! 3.) Be free from sleep-stopping drugs. Alcohol (1-hour metabolic rate for an adult male) should be avoided before bed. Coffee (a 6-hour half-life) should be avoided in the evenings, even if it doesn’t “effect you”. Your sleepy receptors in your brain have been blocked, let your body do its thing. 4.) Make sure you wake up at the correct time in your sleep cycle. I have other writing on this where I go into more depth, but it goes like this: Ever wake up from a nap feeling awesome and ready to go? Ever wake up and feel worse than you did when you laid down? Usually that depends on where you were in your sleep cycle when you woke up Waking up at the correct time in your sleep cycle is not an exact science (although some apps, like SleepCycle, can help) but the easiest thing is to train your body with the same bedtime and wake-up time every day. Your body will learn and know when and how to wake up. While you didn’t get 9 hours sleep, you will feel more refreshed and have a much higher likelihood of getting up ready for the day if you follow these tips. Thanks for reading!

Sleep is an indispensable part of our lives that is essential for our physical and emotional well-being. Getting an inadequate amount of sleep can make a person feel less productive and also damage our brain cells in the long run. Coming back to the original question of how you can sleep 8 hours in 4 hours. A person can consider getting a biphasic or polyphasic sleep for him to be productive throughout the day. Biphasic sleep involves sleeping during two periods in 24 hours while polyphasic sleep involves sleeping 3 or 4 more times. It helps the person to get quality sleep and the person feels more alert and focussed. While this kind of sleep isn’t advisable in the long run, it can help you perform better at work if your work requires you to put in some extra hours. Getting at least 6-7 hours of sleep is essential for every person to be functional and maintain his immunity. A lack of sleep can make a person less immune to infections and diseases. Therefore, if it isn’t possible for you to get a 6-7 hour sleep in one go, you can consider getting a biphasic sleep. You should also make certain changes to your lifestyle such as avoiding caffeine before bed, exercising daily, and indulging in healthy eating to keep yourself in shape and stay productive throughout the day.
